docs.snippet: LEAD:  TENNIS  Graf Bounces Back: Steffi Graf of West Germany came back after losing the first set to beat Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-7, 6-1, 6-3, in the opening round of the Nokia Masters women's tournament yesterday in Essen, West Germany....
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: TENNIS Graf Bounces Back: Steffi Graf of West Germany came back after losing the first set to beat Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-7, 6-1, 6-3, in the opening round of the Nokia Masters women's tournament yesterday in Essen, West Germany. Monica Seles of Yugoslavia breezed by Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-1, and Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina struggled before beating Zina Garrison of Houston, 1-6, 6-3, 6-4.

docs.snippet: LEAD: When Fernando Vaca Narvaja and Roberto Perdia stepped off a hydrofoil boat from Uruguay last month, they looked like two of the well-dressed businessmen who regularly commute to Argentina.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: When Fernando Vaca Narvaja and Roberto Perdia stepped off a hydrofoil boat from Uruguay last month, they looked like two of the well-dressed businessmen who regularly commute to Argentina.

headline.main: Offer by Argentine Leftist Rebels: Gift of Ransom

byline.original: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD:  Skiing  Schneider Captures Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, the defending World Cup champion, who fell on her first run of the season Friday, turned in two flawless runs to win the women's slalom yesterday at Park City, Utah. Schneider,...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Skiing Schneider Captures Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, the defending World Cup champion, who fell on her first run of the season Friday, turned in two flawless runs to win the women's slalom yesterday at Park City, Utah. Schneider, who won 14 times last year, negotiated the 427-meter course at the Park City Ski Area in 47.77 seconds on her first run and in 46.88 on her second for a total of 1:34.65.

docs.snippet: LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-14  Prague's caretaker prime minister, Ladislav Adamec, met for the first time with opposition leaders and then joined Alexander Dubeck at another rally of 500,000 people demanding democratic changes. Page A1

docs.snippet: LEAD: One of Latin America's most deeply rooted democracies went to the polls today, and a middle-of-the-road lawyer appeared on the way to becoming its next president. Voters opted for a leftist coalition to run the Montevideo city government.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: One of Latin America's most deeply rooted democracies went to the polls today, and a middle-of-the-road lawyer appeared on the way to becoming its next president. Voters opted for a leftist coalition to run the Montevideo city government.

headline.main: Uruguayans Elect a President; Victory Is Seen for Centrist Lawyer

byline.original: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: After national elections on Sunday in which a centrist, Luis Alberto Lacalle, was elected President while a Marxist coalition gained control of the Montevideo city government, Uruguayans now say the stage is set for a sharp conflict.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: After national elections on Sunday in which a centrist, Luis Alberto Lacalle, was elected President while a Marxist coalition gained control of the Montevideo city government, Uruguayans now say the stage is set for a sharp conflict.

headline.main: Uruguay's Mixed Election Result May Lead to Conflict

docs.snippet: LEAD: President Bush offered an array of more than a dozen economic and arms proposals to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today as they began their summit meeting, including an end to cold war trade restrictions.

docs.snippet: LEAD: In offering to cut punitively high tariffs on Soviet exports and support observer status for Moscow in the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, President Bush has moved dramatically to encourage the Soviet Union's integration into...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In offering to cut punitively high tariffs on Soviet exports and support observer status for Moscow in the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, President Bush has moved dramatically to encourage the Soviet Union's integration into the global economy.
